Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding differences between legal systems is a central inquiry for scholars of comparative law. The importance of comparative law has increased enormously in recent years due to economic globalization and democratization. The depth and breadth of these comparisons has long been limited by the need to collect data by hand. This project will use machine coding to eliminate this constraint and, in so doing, will vastly expand the nuance and detail that is possible in the comparison of legal systems. The project will analyze the legal codes of a dozen civil law countries (i.e. countries whose private rights and remedies come from a statutory body of rules rather than from judge-made common law) and develop visualization methods so that patterns can be identified quickly. A central unit of analysis will be the internal cross-reference (or the degree to which they refer to other sections of the code), a feature of legal codes that goes back to the Code of Hammurabi, a legal code dating back to almost 3800 years ago in what is now Iraq.

Civil codes vary substantially in the degree to which they contain internal cross-references. This team's preliminary analysis shows that these patterns map to the different philosophies that underlie these bodies of law. For example, the French Civil Code purports to rely on abstract and deductive legal principles while the German Civil Code has been influenced by the idea that legitimacy arises from historical practice. For the French Civil Code, there are very few internal cross-references whereas in the German Civil Code, there is a rich network of cross-references that can be traced back to the first article of the code. Machine coding can thus reveal important and previously unexplored differences in legal codes. The project will develop and define these metrics in a way that will be accessible to comparative scholars as they attempt to understand how and why differences in the law of a country affect outcomes in those countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project evaluated the network structure of the constitutions of 183 countries and the civil codes of 17 countries. The cross-references within each of these legal texts form the networks used in the project. The advantage of this approach is that it allows for the comparisons of legal texts without needing qualitative and subjective judgments about the substantive content of each text. The analysis of these networks demonstrates that these texts cluster together into legal families. These clusters generally track the colonizing country for constitutions and legal tradition for civil codes.

Project Outcomes:

-- Design parsers that can extract the network structure of constitutions (supplied in English by the Comparative Constitutions Project) and civil codes (in native language format from government websites).

-- Analyze the network structure of civil codes in a way that shows the strong relationship between the dominant French and German civil law traditions and the density of cross-reference networks of codes that follow these traditions. Preliminary findings are forthcoming in Badawi & Dari-Mattiacci, Reference Networks and Civil Codes, in Law as Data: Computation, Text, and the Future of Legal Analysis (2018 Santa Fe Institute Press, eds. Michael Livermore and Daniel Rockmore). The attached image shows an example of this analysis.

-- Analyze the network structure of 183 countries in a manner that shows the sharp distinction between the constitutions of common law countries and civil law countries. This distinction is present both in the initial constitution of each country as well as the modern day constitutions of each country. These findings will eventually appear in Badawi et al., Constitutions, Cross-Reference Networks, and Legal Origins.

-- Prepare the network data for publication online. Users will be able to download the raw network data as well as create custom visualizations for each country (the attached image was created using these tools).
